awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Taiwan
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds Ming Eric Tai of Harvard University to conduct a research project in the Math and Physical Sciences area during the summer of 2013 at Academia Sinica in Taipei, Taiwan.  The project title is "Quantum Simulation of Persistent Current in an Ultracold Atomic Gas." The host scientist is Yu-Ju Lin.

Ultracold atomic systems have proven to be a powerful platform for the study of strongly correlated many-body phenomena, such as superconductivity, superfluidity, and quantum magnetism. This project extends the experimental toolbox of these systems by investigating Raman coupling techniques for implementing artificial magnetic fields in neutral atoms and performing benchmark experiments on persistent current and non-classical rotational inertia. The mastery of these techniques provides a direct avenue for studying non-Abelian gauge fields, the quantum Hall effect, and topological insulators in ultracold atoms. The investigation of methods to create artificial magnetic fields is crucial to extending the field of quantum simulation with ultracold atoms. Advances in this field have the potential to simulate and further the understanding of a whole host of exotic materials, such as high-Tc superconductors and spintronic materials-- materials that are not just of scientific curiosity, but instead have already seen use or have proposed applications in computer storage, medical devices, and green energy.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language.   These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.  Furthermore, this experience in Taiwan also further equips the Fellow as an ambassador for science and allows him to speak to the truly global and collaborative nature of science. The Fellow plans to share these experiences not only in the weekly graduate student seminar held in his department, but also to the  aspiring high school students that he meets at the science competitions for which he volunteers as a science judge.

por.por_cntn:
While their familiarity and ubiquity might suggest a thorough understanding, metals--- even Ohm's law metals--- are highly non-trivial systems from which there is much to learn. For example, in spite of Ohm's law asserting that a voltage is required to sustain an electrical current, quantum mechanics dictates that there are conditions under which a resistive ring supports a non-zero current, even in the absence of an applied voltage. This non-zero current that exists even at zero voltage is termed persistent current (PC).  The phenomenon of PC is theoretically well understood for ideal, simple systems, however an explanation that applies for disordered systems remains elusive despite their closer resemblance to resistive metals in which the phenomenon is experimentally observed.

With this EAPSI grant, we proposed to take a new approach to figuring out the mysteries of PC. Unlike previous studies which utilized actual manifestations of metallic resistive circuits, in this project we sought to simulate electrical current in a resistive circuit using an ultracold quantum gas of Rubidium confined to a toroidal trap. This approach represents an example of quantum simulation as first proposed by Feynman in 1982. The idea is to use a highly controllable quantum system, which can be thought of as an analog quantum computer, to simulate another less experimentally accessible quantum system. The highly controllable quantum system in this case is ultracold atoms with all the tools of atomic physics. This platform allows for the continuous tuning of many parameters, e.g. using Feshbach resonances, magnetic fields can tune interaction strengths between atoms; by coupling to the magnetic moment, magnetic fields can produce potential gradients. System parameters, e.g.  potentials and excitation energies, can also be characterized with spectroscopic precision.

For this project, I worked on designing three optics setups. The first optics setup was for generating the toroidal trap used to confine the atoms into a circular loop.  The second optics setup was for generating the Raman coupling necessary in the synthetic magnetic field scheme. The final optics setup was built to test a proposed imaging system.

The results of this project were disseminated at various venues. I gave a talk and presented a poster at a symposium of students in Taiwan. This symposium included graduate student researchers in a variety of fields as well as undergraduate students. Among these undergraduate students were both those that were considering a career in scientific research as well as those involved in non-scientific tracks. When I returned to the United States, I also presented the results from this project at a seminar of graduate students in my field. These students were largely drawn from the Cambridge area. When the complete results of this project are obtained, we plan on writing a paper and publishing in a widely published journal, in addition to the free preprint server, arXiv.
